conclusion: To find the work done externally by the gas from state B to state C, we need to calculate the area under the curve in the p-V diagram from B to C.
From state A to state B, the pressure decreases while the volume remains constant.
From state B to state C, the pressure remains constant while the volume increases.
Pressure at state B is \( p_B = 2 \times 10^5 \, \text{Pa} \).
Volume at state B is \( V_B = 2 \times 10^{-3} \, \text{m}^3 \).
Volume at state C is \( V_C = 3 \times 10^{-3} \, \text{m}^3 \).

premise: The process from B to C is an isobaric process (constant pressure).
conclusion: The work done \( W \) in an isobaric process is given by: \( W = p \Delta V = p_B (V_C - V_B) \).

premise: The work done externally by the gas from state B to state C is \( 2 \times 10^2 \, \text{J} \).
conclusion: State B to State C gas does 200 joules of work externally.
